The reason that the observable Universe have a radius over ~ 13.8 billion light years is because space itself is expanding. As an analogy, consider a person walking relative to the static ground. He/she may walk ~ 5 km in an hour. But let's say he/she is *walking* up a very, very long escalator. Then he/she will still move 5 km in an hour relative to the escalator, but due to the motion of the escalator he/she will still get farther in the same time.

Imagine space as a bunch of tiny cubes, you would describe this as a field. inside each cube "empty" space is actually broiling with particles, quantum foam. because of their energy new particles are always being created, the cube heats up, and space expands. Now imagine trillions of these cubes along your line of sight out to the edge of the OU. Each expanding a little bit at a time. Now do the math to see how fast the outermost cubes along that line are being pushed away from you.

The universe can be "larger then it is old" because of the expansion of the universe. While nothing is moving faster then the speed of light, space itself is expanding, Its a cumulative effect, and at great distances things "appear" to be moving away from us at faster then the speed of light. Actually appear isn't the right word, since that's really when things "disappear" :P

The observable universe is always relative to the observer who sits at the center of it. imagine a sphere around you, and a different sphere around every one of us, the boundary of which is so far distant that light from outside of it hasn't reached us yet. Now imagine that the objects which emit light outside that boundary are expanding away from us so quickly that their light will NEVER reach us. That is the event horizon of the observable universe, now step to the left...

It seems that people keep forgetting that space-time itself exists inside the universe. So when the universe expands, space expands. The speed of light is something that exists inside space-time. Thus there is kind of little meaning in saying that "everything moved away from a point at x speed", when "point" and "speed" (in the same sense as we know them) are terms used in the context of space. It's used a nice simple way to describe the Big Bang, but is a bit misleading in my opinion.
Atoms can't travel faster than the speed of light inside the universe. But since it's the universe itself that is expanding (and physical space with it), it can be faster than that.

My point exactly. Several hundred years ago, science was incredibly rudimentary. The ensuing worship and exaggeration produces such unlikely ideas as Jesus turning water to wine, but, in their view, equally likely as something simple today.

In the extent of human knowledge, yes, many of the events appear to be impossible, at least in the fashion they are told. From my understanding, it’s because at absolute 0 (0 K or ~-273 C) particles have minimal kinetic energy. 
Heat refers to the transfer of kinetic energy. Temperature is the average measurement of kinetic energy of particles. Thus, if there is minimal energy, there is minimal heat and therefore, minimal temperature. (Minimal temperature referring to absolute zero of course.)
This is why it is considered an absolute--there is nothing beyond it, as particles cannot have less than minimal energy.
